PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask., where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: Miss Alice Kildon

Address: Outlook, Sask.

Birthplace: near Hatton, North Dakota, USA

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? ...my parents started housekeeping in the district in 1903, and I have been living there since then.

Where did you set up housekeeping? ...at Hatton, North Dakota, USA.

Where had you been living before that? ...in North Dakota, USA.

For how many people did you prepare meals? ...my mother prepared meals for 5 people and 5 people for my family.

How far was it to your nearest store? ...2 miles away.

In what quantities did you buy your supplies? ...in bulk.

Was flour milled locally? ...yes.

How far away? ...about 1 mile.

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? ...25 cents.

What other grain products did you use? ...corn meal.

Cornmeal? ...yes.

Whole Wheat? ...no.

Farina? ...yes.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? ...yes.

How did you grind it? ...with a mill built at Outlook.

After Outlook was built a mill was built there.

13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? We bought it at first. Later we have made our own soap too.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes. Wood ashes?

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle? Royal Crown Soap in bars.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? We bought it from the woods near the river and from the sand hills 5-6 miles away.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. We began using coal. The first year we had an open hearth (we came in 1903) the farmers were allowed to haul wood from the river banks and sand hills free.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) Yes.

By whom was your first cook stove made? We brought our cook stove back us from the U.S.G.

What year was it purchased? 1894. Price?

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, copper, and tin (not hammered).

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) China, earthenware, and wooden bowls.

When did you first see enamel ware?

Aluminum? Remember buying an aluminum cooking set in 1916 but I think we had some before then also.

We bought our Home Comfort Range Feb 10th 1910 and we used it often for years.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

Remember apples were first shipped in barrels. Rolled oats, flour, meal, sugar etc. first came in cotton bags later paper cartons.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g. winter or summer.

Breakfast: Oatmeal, fried pork and fried potatoes, scrambled eggs, bread, butter, coffee.

Dinner: Bread, butter, meat, potatoes, carrots or other vegetables, green vegetables, unsweetened coffee, tea or milk.

Supper: Meat, potatoes, bread, butter (sometimes apple instead), wheat, coffee, tea or milk, dried apple sauce or other fruits, jelly.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? ...1903

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

Meat Cakes, [bluefish] potatoes, beans + Christmas bread, Wheat bread, Coffee, Christmas cake.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

We always had plenty to eat.
16. TRAFFIC AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the appearance and containers used with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate months, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: Oatmeal, toast, coffee

Lunch: Sandwiches, meat, potatoes, carrots or turnips

Dinner: Meat, potatoes, vegetables, bread, butter, tea, coffee

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada? Give the menu.

Christmas Dinner: Turkey, mashed potatoes, carrots, cranberry sauce, gravy, bread, butter, tea, coffee

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on oats or locally produced foods? Give details.

We always had plenty of food.
